Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Selective Thiol-Ene and Thiol-Yne Chemistry, From First Principles to Organic Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Brian Northrop of Wesleyan University is investigating how to direct chemical reactions to form specific linkages between molecules and form polymers. Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life that utilize plastics, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. These insights will provide more efficient methods for making a variety of materials and for creating new types of materials with novel properties. The results of this research are expected to impact applications such as the development of materials for the targeted delivery of drugs, new consumer care products, and new plastic materials.


In this project Brian Northrop is investigating the fundamental reactivity of thiols with alkenes and alkynes. The research objectives include first principles computational modeling of thiol-ene and thiol-yne reaction mechanisms, small molecule model studies for synthetic testing of selective thiol-ene and thiol-yne reaction conditions, and implementation of these new methods in the synthesis of organic macromaterials. The project integrates these research goals with outreach programs that include hands-on workshops in polymer science for elementary school students and the development of an interdisciplinary program in materials chemistry that will increase the participation and retention of undergraduate students in the sciences. While both thiol-ene and thiol-yne reactions have found broad utility across multiple areas of polymer and materials chemistry there are, at present, few known methods for carrying out selective thiol-ene and thiol-yne reactions, which this research project addresses. This research should enable the development of more efficient means to prepare complex, multifunctional materials with selectively tunable properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on investigating the underlying details of chemical reactions between compounds called thiols and alkenes. Thiols are sulfur-containing molecules and alkenes are molecules with an “unsaturated” carbon-carbon bond capable of forming new covalent bonds with other atoms or molecules. A variety of thiols can be induced to react with an even wider variety of alkenes along what are known, broadly, as “thiol-ene” reactions. Such reactions have been known for a long time; related reactions between sulfur and alkenes date as far back as the vulcanization of rubber in the mid-1800s. More recently, interest in thiol-ene reactions has grown substantially as they have found applications that span multiple areas of chemistry, biochemistry, and materials science including high refractive index materials, dental resins, lithography, hydrogels, polymer synthesis, and drug delivery. Much of the utility of thiol-ene reactions stems from their reliability, high yields, and the variety of ways of initiating or catalyzing the reactions. Methods for promoting thiol-ene reactions include using heat, light, adjusting the pH, or adding catalytic amounts of initiators known as nucleophiles. Despite all their valuable attributes, few methods had been known for carrying out specific thiol-ene reactions selectively from within mixtures containing multiple thiol and/or alkene components. Through this project we discovered several new methods of carrying out selective thiol-ene and, most predominantly, thiol-Michael reactions (where thiol-Michael reactions are a subset of thiol-ene reactions).

 

Our success in developing methods for selective thiol-ene and thiol-Michael reactions was achieved by utilizing a combination of experimental synthesis, analytical characterization, and computational chemical modeling to explore and understand how each component in thiol-ene and thiol-Michael reactions influences reaction efficiency and may enable (or detract from) reaction selectivity. With this multi-pronged approach we elucidated the fundamental details of the reaction mechanism for the most rapid class of thiol-Michael reactions: thiol additions to maleimides. With this deeper understanding of thiol-Michael reaction mechanisms we expanded our analysis to a range of different alkenes, ultimately discovering multiple ternary (three component), quaternary (four component), and ultimately senary (six component) sequential or “one-pot” selective thiol-Michael reactions. We not only developed methods for selective thiol-Michael reactions, we also improved our understanding of the mechanism and outcomes of individual thiol-Michael processes. For example, it had been postulated that initiators of thiol-Michael reactions known as nucleophiles can lead to undesired byproducts. We discovered, however, that only some classes of nucleophiles result in such byproducts and we proved that in other cases, initial byproducts are converted into desired thiol-Michael products. The results are significantly helpful for selecting appropriate reaction conditions. We built on our fundamental studies by demonstrating the utility of combining efficient thiol-maleimide reactions with thermally reversible furan-maleimde chemistry in order to construct a class of highly branched, multi-functional polymers called dendrimers. The new route we discovered is highly modular and can be used to selectively position different branching functionalities within any layer of the growing dendrimer, allowing researchers to fine-tune the properties of these molecules for uses ranging from drug delivery to catalysis to composites. Furthermore, we used our selective thiol-ene methods to design and synthesize branched polymers wherein one “arm” of the polymer can slide along the remainder of the polymer though the two cannot be separated. This type of mechanically linked polymer has dramatically different physical and elastic properties relative to traditional branched polymers.

 

The research activities in this project were carried out with active involvement and training of multiple undergraduate and graduate student researchers, as well as one high school student.
